q: I am the 'brain' of the computer, responsible for processing instructions. What am I?
a: The Central Processing Unit (CPU).

q: What are the three main components of the CPU?
a: Control Unit (CU), Arithmetic Logic Unit (ALU), and Registers.

q: I am the architecture where data and programs are stored in the same memory. What am I?
a: Von Neumann Architecture.

q: What does the ALU do?
a: Performs Arithmetic (maths) and Logical (AND, OR, NOT) operations.

q: What is the function of the Control Unit (CU)?
a: It manages the flow of data and instructions, and coordinates the other parts of the CPU.

q: I hold the address of the NEXT instruction to be fetched. Which register am I?
a: Program Counter (PC).

q: I hold the current instruction being executed. Which register am I?
a: Current Instruction Register (CIR).

q: I am a register that stores the results of calculations from the ALU. What am I?
a: The Accumulator (ACC).

q: What is the purpose of the Memory Address Register (MAR)?
a: To hold the address of the memory location currently being read from or written to.

q: What is the purpose of the Memory Data Register (MDR)?
a: To hold the data or instruction that has just been fetched from memory or is about to be written to it.

q: Describe the Fetch-Decode-Execute cycle.
a: 1. Fetch instruction from memory. 2. Decode the instruction to understand it. 3. Execute the instruction.

q: I am a bus that carries data between the CPU and memory. I am bidirectional. What am I?
a: The Data Bus.

q: I am a bus that carries memory addresses from the CPU to memory. I am unidirectional. What am I?
a: The Address Bus.

q: I am a bus that carries command signals from the CU to other components. What am I?
a: The Control Bus.

q: What is the function of the System Clock?
a: It generates timing signals to synchronise all operations within the computer.

q: What is an Embedded System?
a: A computer system built into a larger device, designed to perform a specific function (e.g., washing machine controller).

q: Give two benefits of Embedded Systems.
a: 1. Low power consumption. 2. Small size. 3. Low cost. 4. Reliable for specific tasks.

q: What is the difference between RAM and ROM?
a: RAM is Volatile (loses data when power is off) and Read/Write. ROM is Non-Volatile and Read-Only.

q: Why does a computer need Cache memory?
a: It is faster than RAM and stores frequently used data/instructions close to the CPU to speed up processing.

q: I am a type of storage that uses magnetic platters. What am I?
a: Hard Disk Drive (HDD).

q: I am a type of storage with no moving parts, using flash memory. What am I?
a: Solid State Drive (SSD).

q: Give two advantages of SSDs over HDDs.
a: Faster access speed, more durable (no moving parts), quieter, consumes less power.

q: What is Virtual Memory?
a: Using a section of the Hard Drive (secondary storage) as an extension of RAM when RAM is full.

q: What is the main disadvantage of using Virtual Memory?
a: It is much slower than real RAM, leading to 'disk thrashing' and reduced performance.

q: I am an input device that reads black and white lines. What am I?
a: A Barcode Scanner.

q: I am an input device that captures physical 3D objects into a digital model. What am I?
a: A 3D Scanner.

q: How does a Resistive Touch Screen work?
a: Two layers touch when pressed, completing a circuit. It is cheaper but doesn't support multi-touch.

q: How does a Capacitive Touch Screen work?
a: It uses the electrical charge of the human body to detect touch. It supports multi-touch and is more durable.

q: I am an output device that creates physical objects layer by layer. What am I?
a: A 3D Printer.

q: Scenario: You need to print high-quality photographs. Which printer do you choose?
a: Inkjet Printer.

q: Scenario: You need to print 1,000 text documents quickly. Which printer do you choose?
a: Laser Printer.

q: What is the difference between LCD and OLED screens?
a: LCD requires a backlight. OLED pixels emit their own light, allowing for thinner screens and deeper blacks.

q: I am a sensor that detects movement. What am I?
a: Motion Sensor (or Infrared Sensor).

q: Scenario: A street light turns on automatically when it gets dark. What sensor is used?
a: Light Sensor.

q: I am a sensor used in a greenhouse to control windows. What might I measure?
a: Temperature or Humidity.

q: What is an Actuator?
a: A mechanical component (like a motor) that moves or controls a mechanism or system, often controlled by a computer.

q: What is a MAC Address?
a: A unique hardware address assigned to a Network Interface Card (NIC) by the manufacturer.

q: What is the difference between Static and Dynamic IP addresses?
a: Static IP never changes (good for servers). Dynamic IP is assigned temporarily by a DHCP server when you connect.
